content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
### Extraction System Inserter at Position(x=-3.5, y=27.5)
Consists of a single extraction system burner inserter whose drop position is (x=-3.5, y=28.5). This device is used to lift extracted items into subsequent belt connections.

### Copper Cable Factory at Position(x=2.5, y=17.5)
Consists of the following interconnected entities:
• Cable Factory Input Chest at (x=2.5, y=17.5) serving as the resource intake.
• New Factory Burner Inserter at (x=3.5, y=17.5) using direction RIGHT, which links production to downstream processing.
 – Neighbouring components include a burner inserter at (x=2.5, y=16.5) and an assembling machine at (x=1.5, y=19.5).  
This structure is intended to process copper plates into copper cables.

### Belt Depot System at Position(x=3.5, y=15.5)
Consists of the following entities forming an intermediary belt connection:
• Wooden Chest (belt depot) placed at (x=3.5, y=15.5) acting as a fixed belt target.
• Transport Belt Segment at (x=4.5, y=15.5) positioned adjacent to the depot chest to extend belt routing.
• Depot Burner Inserter at (x=3.5, y=14.5) using direction UP with a pickup position at (x=3.5, y=15.5) and drop position at (x=3.5, y=13.5).  
Its purpose is to serve as a defined connection node for transferring items between extraction and factory stages.

ERROR TIPS
────────────
• Transport Belt Connection Errors  
 – When connecting transport belts, ensure the target is a valid inserter or similar input device. Avoid selecting objects (e.g. Prototype.SteamEngine) that cannot accept items to prevent connection failures.

• Placement Range Errors  
 – Verify that the player is within the allowed distance of the target placement. Moving closer before attempting placement avoids errors due to exceeding the maximum range.

• Inventory Availability Errors  
 – Confirm that the required item exists in the inventory prior to placement. Missing items (such as a wooden chest) will result in placement errors.

• Variable Definition Errors  
 – Check that all variables are correctly defined and referenced. Typos or undefined variables (for example, using “target_chest” without prior definition) lead to runtime NameErrors.
